biography.bio: Edmond Bennett was born on August 14, 1921 in Haydock, Merseyside, England as William Edward H. Bennett. He was an actor, known for The Chase (1964), Clue of the Twisted Candle (1960) and The Missing Mercury (1959). He was married to Julia Jones. He died on August 27, 1986 in Camden, London, England.
biography.name: Edmond Bennett

biography.bio: A.J. Brown was born on September 14, 1897 in the UK as Alfred John Brown. He was an actor, known for Lord Jim (1965), Hands of the Ripper (1971) and Portrait of Man (1960). He died on January 29, 1978 in Westminster, London, England.
biography.name: A.J. Brown

biography.bio: Richard Caldicot was born on October 7, 1908 in London, England as Richard Caldicot-Bull. He was an actor, known for HMS Paradise (1964), Mountains of the Moon (1990) and Mrs Thursday (1966). He died on October 16, 1995 in London.
biography.name: Richard Caldicot

biography.bio: Francis De Wolff was born on January 7, 1913 in Essex, England. He was an actor, known for From Russia with Love (1963), A Christmas Carol (1951) and Moby Dick (1956). He was married to Linda Finch, Melissa Dundas and Jean Fairlie. He died on April 18, 1984 in Sussex, England.
biography.name: Francis De Wolff

biography.bio: Born in leafy Kew in the English Home Counties, Kenneth Fortescue was a pupil at the prestigious, fee-paying boys' school Dulwich College in London, leaving in 1949 to attend the Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts. Whilst a student there he won the BBC Special Prize, enabling him to act in radio plays. On graduation he made his stage debut in 'The Tempest' at the old Mermaid Theatre directed by actor Bernard Miles and played in repertory companies throughout England, making his film debut as the youngest son in the remake of 'The Barrets of Wimpole Street'. When the war-time film comedy 'Desert Mice' was being cast he went to audition with the producers, stuck his head round their door and said 'Hello' and was told 'You're just what we wanted' and throughout the late 1950s and early 1960s he appeared in several light comedy films as 'silly-ass' young British twits though he was somewhat in the shadow of the more established and slightly older Ian Carmichael who had made such roles his own. The demand for rougher, more down-to-earth young leading men in the British cinema of the 1960s effectively relegated him to character parts and cameos as junior officers, as in 'Lawrence of Arabia', and petty officials, though he did have a good role as the effete, discarded boyfriend, Cecil, in a 1970s television version of 'A Room With A View', and it is a little ironic that his last screen role before his early death was as a cast member of the film-within-a-film in 'The Mirror Crack'd', a throwback to the British cinema of the 1950s when he began his cinema career.
biography.name: Kenneth Fortescue

biography.bio: Gladys Henson was born on September 27, 1897 in Dublin, Ireland as Gladys Gunn. She was an actress, known for The Prince and the Showgirl (1957), The Newcomers (1965) and First Men in the Moon (1964). She was married to Leslie Henson. She died on December 21, 1982 in London, England.
biography.name: Gladys Henson

biography.bio: Hazel Hughes was born on April 21, 1913 in Transvaal, South Africa. She was an actress, known for A Bouquet for Juliet (1961), A Stitch in Time (1963) and The Money (1961). She died on November 16, 1974 in London, England.
biography.name: Hazel Hughes

biography.bio: David Knight was born on January 16, 1928 in Niagara Falls, New York, USA as David Stephen Mintz. He is an actor, known for Nightmare (1964), Across the Bridge (1957) and Chance Meeting (1954). He is married to Wendy McClure. They have two children.
biography.name: David Knight

biography.bio: Simon Lack was born on December 19, 1915 in Cleland, Scotland as Alexander MacAlpine. He was an actor, known for Enemy at the Door (1978), The Proud Valley (1940) and Trog (1970). He died on August 8, 1980 in London, England.
biography.name: Simon Lack

biography.bio: Best remembered as 'M' in the James Bond films, Bernard Lee was a popular character player in British films throughout the 1950s and 1960s. Born into a theatrical family, he made his stage debut at age six and later attended the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art. He first appeared on the West End stage in London in 1928, and continued to work in the theatre during the 1930s, taking only occasional film roles. It was only after World War II that he concentrated his efforts on the cinema, and was much in demand in British films of the 1950s as friendly authority figures, including army sergeants, police detectives or navy officers. Detectives became a particular specialty, and he played this role in more than a dozen films, including The Blue Lamp (1950), Beat the Devil (1953) and The Detective (1954). In the early 1960s, he also made regular appearances as police detectives in the The Edgar Wallace Mystery Theatre (1960) second feature series, usually as "Inspector Meredith". He also made memorable appearances in The Third Man (1949), Operation Disaster (1950), Glory at Sea (1952), Pursuit of the Graf Spee (1956), Dunkirk (1958) and Whistle Down the Wind (1961). He was effectively cast against type in only two films, as the union agitator in The Angry Silence (1960), and as a disgruntled civil servant who becomes a spy for the Russians in Ring of Treason (1964). In 1962, he made his first appearance as the head of the British secret service in the first James Bond film, Dr. No (1962). He went on to be featured in the next ten films in the series, appearing with Sean Connery, George Lazenby and, later, Roger Moore as Bond, and will probably be considered the definitive "M" by more than one generation of Bond fans.
biography.name: Bernard Lee

biography.bio: Harry Locke was born on December 10, 1913 in London, England. He was an actor, known for All at Sea (1957), The L-Shaped Room (1962) and Treasure Island (1950). He died on September 7, 1987 in London.
biography.name: Harry Locke

biography.placeOfBirth: St George in the East, London, England, UK
biography.bio: Alfred Maron was born on April 27, 1912 in St George in the East, London, England as Abraham Alfred Maron. He was an actor, known for The Angry Silence (1960), Eugene O'Neill: Three Plays of the Sea (1960) and Absolute Beginners (1986). He died on September 28, 1986 in Westminster, London.
biography.name: Alfred Maron

biography.bio: Stanley Morgan was born on November 10, 1929 in Liverpool, England. He is an actor, known for Seance on a Wet Afternoon (1964), The L-Shaped Room (1962) and Konga (1961).
biography.name: Stanley Morgan

biography.bio: Roy Purcell was born on January 26, 1919 in Hackney, London, England as Roy Douglas Purcell. He was an actor, known for The Buccaneers (1956), I'm All Right Jack (1959) and The Deadly Females (1976). He died on July 31, 2000 in Surrey, England.
biography.name: Roy Purcell

biography.bio: Christine Shaw was born on May 2, 1932 in England as Christine Annabel Joyce Shaw. She was an actress, known for Revenge of the Pink Panther (1978), The Tiger Lily (1975) and Don't Drink the Water (1974). She died on August 17, 2003 in London, England.
biography.name: Christine Shaw
